title: How to Identify a Maltese Dog

steps.title: Check the dog's size.
steps.content: Check the dog's size. Maltese dogs are rather small. They are only 8–10 inches (20.3–25.4 cm) tall and weigh 4–7 pounds (1.8–3.2 kg). [3] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Look at the eyes.
steps.content: Look at the eyes. The eyes of a Maltese dog are very dark with black rims. They aren't set too far apart, giving the dog a gentle yet alert expression. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Examine the ears.
steps.content: Examine the ears. Maltese dogs have drop ears that are low-set and heavily feathered with long hair that hangs down to their heads. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Notice the muzzle.
steps.content: Notice the muzzle. A Maltese dog's muzzle is medium in length, fine and tapered but not snipy (not to be confused with snippy ). The nose of the dog is black. [6] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Inspect the tail.
steps.content: Inspect the tail. Maltese dogs have a long-haired, plumed tail which is carried over the back of them. [7] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source In show, it's preferred that their tail's tip lies to the side over the hind quarter. steps.title: View the overall structure.
steps.content: View the overall structure. A Maltese dog has a compact structure, with sloped shoulder-blades and elbows that are held close to the body. Their legs are fine-boned, and their hind legs are strong and moderately angulated. Their feet are small, round and tufty. steps.title: Check the coat's texture and appearance.
steps.content: Check the coat's texture and appearance. A Maltese's coat is silky, long, and straight. steps.title: Recognise the coat colour.
steps.content: Recognise the coat colour. Maltese dogs are almost always purely white, although they may have light tan or ivory colourings on their ears. [13] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source Most Maltese are born with biscuit coloured ears and slight markings on the coat, but these usually fade once the dog is 2 years old.

steps.title: Look at the 'cut'.
steps.content: Look at the 'cut'. Some people choose to give their Maltese specific haircuts rather than keeping it the standard cut. steps.title: Notice fearlessness.
steps.content: Notice fearlessness. Despite their small size, Maltese don't fear a thing. They'll greet every stranger and animal as if they were their new best friend. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Look for affection.
steps.content: Look for affection. Maltese dogs are very affectionate and loyal, wanting their owner's attention whenever they can get it. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Watch for activeness.
steps.content: Watch for activeness. The Maltese is just as active inside as it is outside. They'll occupy themselves with other things to do when they're indoors. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Pay attention to intelligence.
steps.content: Pay attention to intelligence. Maltese dogs are smart and quick learners, which makes training them easier. [22] X Research source

steps.title: See if the dog is gentle.
steps.content: See if the dog is gentle. Maltese dogs are naturally gentle and sweet-tempered. Maltese dogs are nearly never aggressive, so they are generally alright to have around children. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Tell if a dog is a Maltese or a Bichon Frise.
steps.content: Tell if a dog is a Maltese or a Bichon Frise . The Bichon Frise is a very similar dog to the Maltese. Both are a part of the Bichon family, which are all petite mostly white coloured breeds. This means the two have a very similar appearance, but with some notable differences. The Bichon Frise is generally much larger, with their height ranging from 9–12 inches (22.9–30.5 cm) tall and weight from 12–18 pounds (5.4–8.2 kg). The Bichon has curlier and denser hair, whilst the Maltese has longer straight hair, if grown out.

steps.title: Notice how Maltese and Shih Tzu differ.
steps.content: Notice how Maltese and Shih Tzu differ. Shih Tzu are another very similar breed to the Maltese. Both breeds are in the toy group and can appear quite similar on a first glance. The Shih Tzu is quite a bit bigger than the Maltese (ranging from 9–10.5 inches), but the Maltese has larger eyes. [24] X Research source Shih Tzu have a double layered coat whereas the Maltese only has one. [25] X Research source The Maltese is only white coloured but Shih Tzu can be any colour, and Shih Tzu generally bark less. [26] X Research source

steps.title: Spot the differences between a Maltese and a Havanese.
steps.content: Spot the differences between a Maltese and a Havanese . Havanese and Maltese dogs have much in common. Both dogs descended from the Bichon family of dogs. The Havanese and the Maltese both have coats that can be grown to floor length, but the Havanese's coat can be a variety of colours, opposed to the Maltese's white coat. The Havanese's height ranges from 8.5–11.5 inches (21.6–29.2 cm) tall which means they can usually be bigger than most Maltese.

steps.title: Know if a dog is a Maltese or a Yorkie.
steps.content: Know if a dog is a Maltese or a Yorkie . Yorkshire Terriers (Yorkies) and Maltese have some similar traits, but they have some very different traits that will help you differentiate them. Both dogs have fur that can grow long, but a Yorkie has a much darker coat. Maltese are white, whereas the Yorkshire Terrier is always a darker colour. The two breeds are very similar in height and weight.
